Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of 3-D Fracture-Site Motion in Supracondylar Femoral Fractures

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: Sixty-six patients with supracondylar femoral fractures (OTA/AO classification of 33A or 33C) were included. Participants were eligible if they had a supracondylar femoral fracture and were treated with locking-plate fixation.

Intervention.evidence: Construct-specific finite element (FE) modeling simulated 3-D fracture-site motion.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effect of three-dimensional (3-D) fracture-site motion on callus formation in supracondylar femoral fractures treated with locking-plate fixation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was callus formation, assessed radiographically at six, twelve, and twenty-four weeks postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty-six participants were randomised, with 33 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Longitudinal motion promoted callus formation at twelve and twenty-four weeks (p = 0.017 for both), while shear inhibited callus formation (p = 0.017 and p = 0.022, respectively).
